@wonook Excellent! Can you close this PR until it is ready, then?

I've done a pass. A couple of overarching thoughts:
- The API is pretty `string` heavy. Not sure whether this will come back to haunt us, memory wise.
- Please consider making most classes `sealed`, such that inheriting from them doesn't become part of our API.

Also, the API seems very much like Java expressed in C#. Which is unsurprising, given where we took inspiration from. A couple of ideas come to mind to make better use of C#:
- Filters could be expressions from `T` to `bool`
- `MetricsSource` could be an `IObservable<MetricsType>`
- `MetricsSink` could be `IObserver<MetricsType>`
LGTM, will test.

@markusweimer if REEF-1478 is no more a blocking issue, then I believe the PR is ready to be reviewed ðŸ˜„
@johnyangk could you also help reviewing the PR please?

@markusweimer 

> Please consider making most classes sealed

Will do that.

> The API is pretty string heavy.

 I am not sure what you exactly mean - Do you mean that storing name and info for each metric, record etc. is memory intensive. Any suggestion there?

> Filters could be expressions from T to bool

I can make all the functions inside the class as expressions.

> MetricsSource could be an IObservable<MetricsType>

Let me think about this and get back.

@markusweimer 

> MetricsSource could be an IObservable<MetricsType>
>    MetricsSink could be IObserver<MetricsType>

I am not sure if MetricsSource and MetricsSink together qualify for IObservable and IObserver interface. Like in metrics2, we also might want the flow of metrics from source to sink to be asynchronous. For example, source puts metrics in a queue and sink in a separate thread will pull metrics from queue. The maximum length of the queue in turn allows us to make sure that too much memory is not consumed by metrics process and also allows to have the logic of specifying what to do if queue is full (for example sources should hang or just drop metrics.).

On the other hand, MetricsSource and actual metrics like counters and gauges might qualify for IObservable IObserver relationships since when MetricsSource is asked to fill in the metrics records, it can call OnNext of different metrics.

Similarly MetricsSink can be IObserver<MetricsRecord> , with appropriate IObservable defined in the default implementations which in the example above would be the queue implementation in which records are being pushed.

Does that make sense?
LGTM. We could also turn this into a unit test to make sure we don't break the functionality. But maybe we can do that in a separate JIRA?

> For example, source puts metrics in a queue and sink in a separate thread will pull metrics from queue.

I don't see why this can't be done in Rx. It is precisely what Rx is for: flowing events through a series of operators, one of which could be a queue.

In general, the API is fairly Java-ish. In C#, we could offer neat things like `_counters["BytesRead"] += 7` or `_bytesReadCounter.OnNext(7)` which would look a lot nicer in client code. Would such an API be layered on top of what we are reviewing here? Or is this neatness an intrinsically bad idea?

I haven't looked into this example closely, but we seem to have several TestSuspendTask\* tests in O.A.R.Evaluator.Tests and TestSuspendTask in O.A.R.Tests.Functional.Bridge. Is the functionality in this example different from what is covered by the tests?
My bad, I haven't noticed that this change deals with Java code, and the tests I remembered are from .NET code. Please disregard my comment, indeed there seems to be no test for suspend on Java side.
LGTM will test & merge

LGTM. Will test and merge.

Hi, @shsundr .
You had better change the title and commit message like the other PRs. There is a format in REEF.
The following is the commit log format for your issue. The title usually be the same with the first line of commit message.
Also, in JIRA, you need to add link by 'Link' menu inside 'More' button of your JIRA.

```
[REEF-1499] Fix CoreCLR incompatibility in Tang

Your description.....

JIRA:
  [REEF-1499](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1499)

This closes #1080
```
Why?
@zerg-junior Thanks, I've updated everything. Would you like to take another look and kindly merge this, if possible?
I created a new pull request #1081 with the properly formatted commit message
Oh, you can use `git commit --amend` and `git push -f` for that purpose.
Yep, or rebase.

Thanks,  I will use rebase next time, if necessary
-Shiv

should we change the scope of Reef 1449?

Shiv

I initially thought I could make REEF 1449 a subtask of a subtask encompasing all of Tang's incompatibilities ...but I can't find anything online that says you can make subtask of subtask in JIRA. So  I modified the title of [REEF-1499](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1499) to be more specific so it only encompasses the single issue: "Fix CoreCLR incompatibility for isDefined function in Tang Reflection Utilities". 
Is this okay?

Sure that would work.
Shravan

If there are multiple types of issues detected by portability analyzer but each of them occurs only once or twice, it's possible to combine several different issues in one JIRA, by listing types of issues in JIRA details. This would reduce the amount of "paperwork" (JIRAs, pull requests and reviews done for them).

@markusweimer, @jwang98052 Could you look at this PR?

This error means that 48 functional tests failed. Transient failures of tests in AppVeyor happen much less frequently and not on all of these tests. I'd say it's very likely that this change actually breaks something; C# side of the code relies on Java side, so it's possible to break C# tests when modifying only Java code. Have you ran C# tests locally?

At a glance, you're modifying Avro scheme of some object - typically this means that you need to modify C# side of handling this object as well.

Thanks a lot, @tcNickolas.

@jwang98052  looked at PR. One comment: looking at FileBasedInputPartition, it should now create instance of T  and store it in a local variable when Cache is called. Shouldn't that change also be part of this PR or you want to do it as a separate one? Otherwise LGTM.

I looked at `MutableMetrics`. A couple of questions:
- Can you explain what makes them mutable vs. the other metrics? Wouldn't e.g. `MutableCounter` emit immutable records into the metrics system? 
- I'm a bit concerned with making`MutableCounter` a public type users of the API interact with, as opposed to calling it e.g. `ICounter`. At the very least, we should have that layer of interfaces for the API not to bind user code to implementation classes.
- There are many `public` classes in this PR. Which makes me nervous, as it means that we commit to those classes in our public APIs. Can you please do a pass and make everything `internal` that you think can be `internal`?
- [C# doesn't allow the assignment operator to be overloaded](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/8edha89s%28v=vs.71%29.aspx). Hence, overloading `+` is dangerous. Also, this currently overloads `+` in a way where the left operand gets mutated, which violates the expectations of such an operator. We might have to drop this nice API simplification.
- What changed in the solutions file?
@dkm2110 Ping. Should this be closed, for now?
@jwang98052 yes thats what I am talking about.

> Can you explain what makes them mutable vs. the other metrics? Wouldn't e.g. MutableCounter emit immutable records into the metrics system?

So, Mutable here means users can modify them. Internally, when IMetricsRecordBuilder functions will be called for example by MutableCounter, it will be stored as IMMutableCounter type of object.

> I'm a bit concerned with makingMutableCounter a public type users of the API interact with, as opposed to calling it e.g. ICounter

I had to do this since operator overloading functions are static and cannot be part of interface. Now that we plan to get rid of them I can do this.

> There are many public classes in this PR. Which makes me nervous, 

Will do a pass.

> C# doesn't allow the assignment operator to be overloaded. Hence, overloading + is dangerous

I propose removing this operator overloading.

> What changed in the solutions file?

Nothing should have. Will take care.
@markusweimer  replied to your overall main concerns...will send another PR soon.

> So, Mutable here means users can modify them. Internally, when IMetricsRecordBuilder functions will be called for example by MutableCounter, it will be stored as IMMutableCounter type of object.

In that case, I suggest to clean up the user facing names in the API. We could rename `MutableCounter` `ICounter` and the values collected by it (which would now be called simply `Counter`, as they are immutable) to `CounterValue`. Does this make sense to you?
@dkm2110 I've responded to your comments. I agree with the ones I did not respond to.
